p: In recent years, there has been a dramatic shift towards a more sustainable, eco-friendly, and natural way of living. Many researchers are of the opinion that there is an alarming increase in drug resistance worldwide and the problem is escalating tremendously, thus rendering the current antimicrobial agents ineffective [ 1, 2, 3]. Approximately two million people worldwide are infected with antibiotic-resistant pathogens, resulting in at least 23,000 mortalities per annum [ 4]. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has emerged as one of the most serious public health concerns of the 21st century [ 5]. Moreover, due to the many disadvantages and side effects associated with current antimicrobial agents, it is not surprising that a large proportion of individuals, especially those who live in developing countries, are utilizing naturally available bioactive alternatives for their primary healthcare.
